newsitem.title: TURKEY: Cyprus power balance change unacceptable - Turkey.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus power balance change unacceptable - Turkey.

text.p: Turkey said on Monday it would not accept a change in the balance of power on the divided island of Cyprus as a result of the Cypriot government's decision to buy Russian surface-to-air missiles.
"We will not tolerate any developments which can change the balance between Turkey and Greece in the eastern Mediterranean," Foreign Ministry spokesman Omer Akbel told a news briefing.
Akbel said Ankara would not accept any development that could endanger the breakaway Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, recognised only by Turkey.
"For these purposes we will take the necessary actions," he said, without expanding.
Cyprus has been divided since 1974 when Turkey invaded and occupied its northern third after a coup engineered by the military ruling in Greece at the time.
The Mediterranean island is one of the world's most heavily militarised areas and 30,000 Turkish troops are stationed in its north.
The Cyprus News Agency said on Saturday that Cyprus had concluded a contract to buy surface-to-air missiles from Russia.
Turkey's Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller voiced annoyance over the planned missile sale during a visit to Russia last month.
Akbel said Turkish officials believed the missiles could also have offensive uses and had contacted Moscow on the issue.

"What we say to Russian authorities, first, is to remind them of their special responsibilities as a (U.N.) Security Council permanent member, secondly, not to change the balance in the island," he said.
